Comments: One of: CMPT 125, CMPT 126, or CMPT 129
One of: MATH 150, MATH 151, MATH 154, or MATH 157
One of: MATH 152, MATH 155, or MATH 158

Title: Career Development Seminar for Statistics and Actuarial Science
Description: A seminar primarily for students undertaking a major or an honors program in Statistics. Visiting speakers share experience relevant to Statistics students and provide useful education and career advice.
Prerequisites: Enrollment, or intended enrollment, in either the Statistics or Actuarial Science major or honors, or permission of the instructor.

Title: Introduction to Analysis I
Description: Mathematical induction. Limits of real sequences and real functions. Continuity and its consequences. The mean value theorem. The fundamental theorem of calculus. Series.
Prerequisites: MATH 152; or MATH 155 or 158 with a grade of B.

Title: Calculus III
Description: Rectangular, cylindrical and spherical coordinates. Vectors, lines, planes, cylinders, quadric surfaces. Vector functions, curves, motion in space. Differential and integral calculus of several variables. Vector fields, line integrals, fundamental theorem for line integrals, Green's theorem.
Prerequisites: MATH 152; or MATH 155 or MATH 158 with a grade of at least B; It is recommended that MATH 240 or 232 be taken before or concurrently with MATH 251.

Title: Introduction to Data Science
Description: Introduction to modern tools and methods for data acquisition, management, and visualization capable of scaling to Big Data.
Prerequisites: A first course in computer programming, such as CMPT 120, and either a first course in statistics - such as STAT 101, STAT 201, or STAT 270 - or 30 units.

Title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
Description: Basic laws of probability, sample distributions. Introduction to statistical inference and applications.
Prerequisites: MATH 152 or 155 or 158. Students wishing an intuitive appreciation of a broad range of statistical strategies may wish to take STAT 100 first.

Title: Intermediate Probability and Statistics
Description: This course is a continuation of STAT 270. Review of probability models, procedures for statistical inference from survey results and experimental data. Statistical model building. Elementary design of experiments and regression methods. Introduction to categorical data analysis.
Prerequisites: Prerequisite: STAT 270. Prerequisite or corequisite MATH 232 or MATH 240.

Title: Introduction to Analysis II
Description: Sequences and series of functions, topology of sets in Euclidean space, introduction to metric spaces, functions of several variables.

Title: Complex Variables
Description: Functions of a complex variable, differentiability, contour integrals, Cauchy's theorem, Taylor and Laurent expansions, method of residues.

Title: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
Description: Review of probability and distributions. Multivariate distributions. Distributions of functions of random variables. Limiting distributions. Inference. Sufficient statistics for the exponential family. Maximum likelihood. Bayes estimation, Fisher information, limited distributions of MLEs. Likelihood ratio tests.

Title: Introduction to Statistical Computing and Exploratoty Data Analysis - R
Description: Introduces the R statistical package. Data management; reading, editing and storing statistical data; data exploration and representation; summarizing data with tables, graphs and other statistical tools; and data simulation.
Prerequisites: STAT 285 or STAT 302 or STAT 305 or equivalent.

Title: Introduction to Statistical Computing and Exploratoty Data Analysis - SAS
Description: Introduces the SAS statistical package. Data management; reading, editing and storing statistical data; data exploration and representation; summarizing data with tables, graphs and other statistical tools; and data simulation.

Title: Linear Models in Applied Statistics
Description: Theory and application of linear regression. Normal distribution theory. Hypothesis tests and confidence intervals. Model selection. Model diagnostics. Introduction to weighted least squares and generalized linear models.

Title: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
Description: Review of discrete and continuous probability models and relationships between them. Exploration of conditioning and conditional expectation. Markov chains. Random walks. Continuous time processes. Poisson process. Markov processes. Gaussian processes.
Prerequisites: STAT 330, or all of: STAT 285, MATH 208, and MATH 251

Title: Statistical Analysis of Sample Surveys
Description: An introduction to the major sample survey designs and their mathematical justification. Associated statistical analyses.

Title: Statistical Design and Analysis of Experiments
Description: An extension of the designs discussed in STAT 350 to include more than one blocking variable, incomplete block designs, fractional factorial designs, and response surface methods.

Title: Statistical Theory
Description: Distribution theory, methods for constructing tests, estimators, and confidence intervals with special attention to likelihood methods. Properties of the procedures including large sample theory.
Prerequisites: STAT 330, or all of: STAT 285, MATH 208, and MATH 251

Title: Bayesian Statistics
Description: The Bayesian approach to statistics is an alternative and increasingly popular way of quantifying uncertainty in the presence of data. This course considers comparative statistical inference, prior distributions, Bayesian computation, and applications.

Title: Applied Discrete Data Analysis
Description: Introduction to standard methodology for analyzing categorical data including chi-squared tests for two- and multi-way contingency tables, logistic regression, and loglinear (Poisson) regression.
Prerequisites: STAT 302 or STAT 305 or STAT 350 or equivalent.

Comments:
An additional three courses in upper division ACMA, MACM, MATH, or STAT courses (excluding STAT 301, 302, 305, 403)and 9 additional units in upper division ACMA, MACM, MATH or STAT courses (excluding STAT 301, 302, 305, 403). Consult an advisor before selecting these courses. The following are recommended.

MACM 316 - Numerical Analysis I (3)
STAT 300W - Statistics Communication (3)
STAT 440 - Learning from Big Data (3)
STAT 445 - Applied Multivariate Analysis (3)
STAT 485 - Applied Time Series Analysis (3)
STAT 490 - Selected Topics in Probability and Statistics (3)
STAT 495 - Directed Studies in Probability and Statistics (3)
